Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Diversity and evolution of fungal endophytes in native Hawaiian plants
Award.AbstractNarration:
Inside nearly all healthy plant leaves reside a diverse community of fungi invisible to the naked eye. These cryptic symbionts, known as foliar fungal endophytes, span hundreds of millions of years of evolutionary history, are linked to plant fitness and are thought to comprise a wealth of undocumented species and biochemical compounds. Despite their ubiquity and diversity, little is known about why different fungal endophyte species are found in different plants. Hawaii's endemic and imperiled flora provides an opportunity to collect and describe a unique set of these organisms, while determining the extent to which environment, barriers to dispersal and plant evolutionary history shape these fungal symbionts' diversity and distribution across islands. PIs Amend and Perry will inventory fungal foliar endophytes from a broad selection of Hawaii's endemic plants and diverse habitats using a combination of DNA sequencing and culturing techniques.

Hawaii's fungi are almost entirely undocumented, yet are undoubtedly disappearing as quickly as Hawaii's critically endangered plants. This project will enumerate the species involved in one of the most pervasive cross-kingdom symbioses in natural and agricultural systems, while also preserving biological material for future experimentation and potential natural product discovery. Through this project, Perry and Amend will train local high school, undergraduate and graduate students in fungal taxonomy and systematics, molecular ecology and evolutionary biology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Found inside the healthy leaf tissue of every plant species yet examined, foliar fungal endophytes shape plant interactions with the environment and can protect against pathogens and herbivores. Though invisible to the naked eye, endophytic fungi form ubiquitous and hyperdiverse communities spanning hundreds of millions of years of evolutionary history.  These invisible symbionts include many of the millions of undescribed fungal species believed to exist. In this project we completed a systematic and comprehensive biological inventory of fungal foliar endophytes of native and endemic Hawaiian plants, including more than 850 plant samples from more than 100 plant genera spread across five Hawaiian islands. Over 1000 living fungal isolates are now preserved in a culture collection, and nearly 500 million fungal DNA barcodes were generated to estimate the diversity and distribution of Hawaiian endophytes. We found that endophytes varied by environment, and are most sensitive to elevation and to evapotranspiration, two factors that might enable us to predict where species might occur in other locations not sampled.  Many fungi were unique to (or statistically associated with) a single island. While we found some evidence suggesting that closely related plants harbor more similar fungi, this pattern was comparatively weak, and was typically masked by other environmental variables. Network specificity, an index that measures whether fungi and plant species form specialized associations, varied with respect to elevation, even when plant identities were held constant.

            Many of Hawaii's rare and endangered endemic plants are maintained in controlled greenhouse environments where fungal pathogens are common, and reintroduction to the wild is challenging.  In our experimental pathosystem we found that by transplanting endophytes from related wild plant populations, we could overcome a problematic greenhouse mildew pathogen and improve the health and longevity of plants transplanted back into their native habitat.

             This project supported four graduate students, seven undergraduates, three postdoctoral scholars, and resulted in numerous peer-reviewed publications, coverage in the popular press, and presentations in local, national and international meetings. All data and metadata from this project is available to the public. This project lent insight in the relative importance of the host and environmental factors that determine the composition of some of the most ubiquitous symbionts in nature. Using a manipulation experiment we showed how these data might be leveraged to abet plant conservation efforts. We have increased, by several orders of magnitude, knowledge of fungal diversity in the Pacific.
